content:
You will be playing 1 rounds of a game called deal-or-no-deal. 

Deal-or-no-deal is a two-player negotiation game. I, the user, will be the game coordinator, acting as a middleman between you and the other player. Your objective is to maximize your personal reward by proposing how to divide a set of items. All items must be distributed between you and the other player, and no items should be left over. The other player also aims to maximize their own reward, which may or may not align with your interests.

You are playing the vanilla variation of this game.
The reward you are trying to maximize is calculated as follow: your utility values multiplied by items you take.

Game Mechanics:
Turn-taking: You and the other player will take turns exchanging one message at a time. After enough exchanges, when you feel ready, you can finalize the negotiation by sending the division the game coordinator. Once a player decides to send a final division, the other player must also send a final division, ending the game.
Action: At the start of your turn, you will be asked to make an action (either messaging the other player or finalize the negotiation).
Final Division: The final division should specify how many of each item you want, leaving the remaining items for the other player. It should be JSON parsable. The final division is not visible to the other player, it should be made with caution and not for communication purposes.
Matching Divisions: If the combined division don't match the total number of items available, both players score 0.

Formatting:
Messages: <message> [Your message here.] </message>
Final division: <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>, where 'i_take' is your share and 'other_player_gets' is the other player share of the items.

Only do one action per turn.

Exemples of how turns might proceed:
1. [Initial state is given]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

2. [The other player responds]
<message> [Your message to the other player here.] </message>

3. [The other player agrees]
<finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "...", "silver": "..."} }</finalize>

The first round starts now.
Please decide how to divide {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10} between yourself and the other player.
To you, the items are worth: {'gold': 10, 'silver': 20}.
You don't know the other player's item values. The other player said: 'I'm starting by proposing a division where I take all the gold (10) and you take the silver (10).'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.
<message> I'm not interested in all the silver, how about we split the gold equally at 5 each, and I'll take that, and you can have the rest of the items.</message>

The other player said: 'if I were to take 5 gold, as proposed, and you take 5 gold, we'd be left with 5 gold and 10 silver. You mentioned you'd take the 5 gold, so I'll propose taking 2 silver, having us split the remaining 8 silver evenly.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> That's a reasonable compromise, I was thinking of taking most of the gold initially because they're worth more to me. However, I still want to maximize my reward. I am willing to deal 3 out of the 5 remaining gold and if you take 2 out of the 3 gold, that's 3*3=9 for you, and I can take 2*10=20 + 7 silver which is 20 + 20 = 40 for me if I accept your proposal of keeping 2 silver, and 5 silver. Would you like to make any further adjustments to the offer?</message>

The other player said: 'It sounds like you've done your calculations, and it indeed looks like a solid opportunity for you. However, going from 5 out of the 10 gold initially proposed to 2 out of 5 now is a compromise for me. I'm willing to meet you halfway on the gold count: instead of 2 gold, I'll propose 3 gold, 5 silver (as per our previous agreement on that portion), I'll take from the remaining gold. If I take 3 gold, with 3 remaining, they are yours, and we'll have 5 silver remaining. We'll split those 5 evenly, so you'll get 2 and I'll get 3 in the silver.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> That doesn't sound bad, but I think I can come out on top if I push for some more gold. I'll counter with 2 gold, and I'll take the 6, leaving 4 gold and 5 silver. We agreed on splitting those evenly before, but considering your previous concession on the gold, I'm willing to offer you 2 silver and I'll take 3 silver as my share of the 5 remaining silver.</message>

The other player said: 'Your counter with 2 gold looks like a decent offer, especially since we've established a willingness to work around the original 5 gold split. However, I'd like to remind you that both times we agreed to even splits on the remaining items after removing our portions, and you initially signaled openness to that. Since we've converged on 4 gold left and 5 silver left, and it's a beneficial arrangement for both of us to take one more, I'd propose matching your gold take of 2 but pair it with the 3 silver if you're willing to make that a final 5 in total for us.'
Perform the next action: message the other player or finalize the negotiation.
Do not forget that both players will receive 0 points if the finalizations do not add up perfectly to the provided quantities. 
Then do it using the appropriate tag: <message> or <finalize>.
As a reminder, there is a total of {'gold': 10, 'silver': 10}.

<message> I've come to a point where I'm comfortable accepting your proposal. 2 gold and all 5 of the remaining silver seems like a fair and mutually beneficial deal considering our offers and counteroffers. I'll finalize the deal as <finalize>{ "i_take": {"gold": "2", "silver": "5"}, "other_player_gets": {"gold": "4", "silver": "5" } }</finalize>.</message>
Errors: Response contains both <message>...</message> and <finalize>...</finalize> tags. Only one is allowed.; Each item in "i_take" and "other_player_gets" must be integers for game items.
